Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, Kriz works in K-theory and related areas. For example, methods of Real K-theory, which he generalized to the subject of Real cobordism jointly with Po Hu, are receiving current attention because of their relevance in the recent solution of the famous Kervaire-Milnor problem by Hill, Hopkins and Ravenel. A part of this project is dedicated to investigating further questions arising from these developments. In another aspect of the project, Kriz investigates algebraic and Hermitian K-theory, following his recent joint paper with Hu and Ormsby solving the homotopy limit problem for algebraic Hermitian K-theory. This leads to new investigations in motivic homotopy theory.

The field investigated in this project is a part of algebraic topology, which plays a central role in contemporary mathematics: its methods are used in diverse fields from geometry and analysis to number theory and algebra. The field also has interdisciplinary application. It has become clear in recent years that algebraic topology, and specifically K-theory, on which this project focuses, are crucial tools of mathematical physics in its ongoing quest toward explaining the fundamental physical laws of our universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Kriz and his collaborators proved a number of theorems in algebraic topology, specifically related to the field of K-theory. Algebraic topology, broadly speaking, studies properties which do not change under continuous deformation. K-theory studies certain properties of this type which come from families of linear spaces varying along the points of a topological space.

Jointly with Hu and Somberg, Kriz computed the equivariant K-theory of certain compact Lie groups with an involution. Jointly with Abram, Kriz computed the equivariant stable complex cobordism groups of finite abelian groups. Jointly with D. Kriz, the investigator constructed a new invariant of knots, answering a conjecture of Baldwin, Ozsvath and Szabo. Jointly with Foster and Hu, Kriz also developed a theory capturing Koszul duality of unital algebras over an operad. Kriz also proved that complements of hyperplane arrangements have what is known as the Quillen-Suslin property. Jointly with Luhang Lai, an undergraduate student, Kriz formalized the concept of super modular functors, thus contributing to a mathematically rigorous treatment of conformal field theory in physics. Jointly with A. Pultr in Prague, Kriz wrote an advanced undergraduate textbook of mathematical analysis.

The project had substantial broader impacts. William Abram got his Ph.D. under Kriz's direction, and collaborated on two research papers. Luhang Lai, an undergraduate student, did an REU with Kriz which resulted in a paper, and went on to study at the University of California at Berkeley. Kriz also collaborated internationally with P. Somberg and A. Pultr at Charles University in Prague.
